item.title: [TUT] Methods
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

Haha, sweet Big Grin Although your naming conventions are a bit odd -- traditionally UPPER_CASE is used for constants. Don't mind me, I'm a conventions nazi.

But they don’t change, now do they?
Technically they are constants. Make them final and gut the constructor if you want to go all “TOTEN SIE NAMING CONVENTION” on me

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT] Methods
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:16, topic:12136”][code]public class Car
{

String NAME, MANU, MODL;
int YEAR;
public static void main(String[] args) 
{
	Car c = new Car();
	c.startEngine();
	c.revEngine();
	c.floorIt();
	c.driveIntoPole();
	c.blowUp();
}

public Car()
{
	this.NAME = "Mr. Vroomy";
	this.MANU = "Yugo";
	this.YEAR = 1876;
	this.MODL = "POS";
}
public void startEngine()
{
	try
	{
		System.out.print("Crank...");
		Thread.sleep(1000);
		System.out.print("Crank...");
		Thread.sleep(1100);
		System.out.print("Crank...");
		Thread.sleep(500);
		System.out.println("Pop..VROOOM!");
	}
	catch (Exception e) {System.out.println("Crank...Crank...Crank...Pop..VROOM!");}
}
public void revEngine()
{
	try
	{
		System.out.print("Vroom....");
		Thread.sleep(1000);
		System.out.println("VROOOOOOM");
	}
	catch (Exception e) {System.out.println("Broom....VROOOOOOM");}
}
public void floorIt()
{
	try
	{
		System.out.print("VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOM");
		Thread.sleep(1000);
		System.out.print("*click*");
		Thread.sleep(400);
		System.out.println("VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOMMM");
	}
	catch (Exception e) {System.out.println("VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOM*click*VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOMMM");}
}
public void driveIntoPole()
{
	System.out.println(YEAR + " " + MANU + " " + MODL + " CRASHES INTO A POLE");
}
public void blowUp()
{
	System.out.println(YEAR + " " + MANU + " " + MODL + " BLOWS UP IN A FIREBALL OF DOOM");
	System.out.println("[" + NAME + "]: o fak did i hit somtin?");
}

}[/code][/quote]
Haha, sweet
Although your naming conventions are a bit odd – traditionally UPPER_CASE is used for constants. Don’t mind me, I’m a conventions nazi.

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT] Methods
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[code]public class Car
{

String NAME, MANU, MODL;
int YEAR;
public static void main(String[] args) 
{
	Car c = new Car();
	c.startEngine();
	c.revEngine();
	c.floorIt();
	c.driveIntoPole();
	c.blowUp();
}

public Car()
{
	this.NAME = "Mr. Vroomy";
	this.MANU = "Yugo";
	this.YEAR = 1876;
	this.MODL = "POS";
}
public void startEngine()
{
	try
	{
		System.out.print("Crank...");
		Thread.sleep(1000);
		System.out.print("Crank...");
		Thread.sleep(1100);
		System.out.print("Crank...");
		Thread.sleep(500);
		System.out.println("Pop..VROOOM!");
	}
	catch (Exception e) {System.out.println("Crank...Crank...Crank...Pop..VROOM!");}
}
public void revEngine()
{
	try
	{
		System.out.print("Vroom....");
		Thread.sleep(1000);
		System.out.println("VROOOOOOM");
	}
	catch (Exception e) {System.out.println("Broom....VROOOOOOM");}
}
public void floorIt()
{
	try
	{
		System.out.print("VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOM");
		Thread.sleep(1000);
		System.out.print("*click*");
		Thread.sleep(400);
		System.out.println("VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOMMM");
	}
	catch (Exception e) {System.out.println("VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOM*click*VROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOMMM");}
}
public void driveIntoPole()
{
	System.out.println(YEAR + " " + MANU + " " + MODL + " CRASHES INTO A POLE");
}
public void blowUp()
{
	System.out.println(YEAR + " " + MANU + " " + MODL + " BLOWS UP IN A FIREBALL OF DOOM");
	System.out.println("[" + NAME + "]: o fak did i hit somtin?");
}

}[/code]

item.title: [TUT] Methods
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

soo much easier example of methods

public class Methods {
public void print(String text)
{
System.out.print(text);
}
}

public class runmymethods {

private static Methods m;

public static void main(String[] args)
{
m.print(“Noob”);
}

}

item.title: [TUT] Methods
item.dc:creator: @newguy45 newguy45
item.description:
@newguy45 wrote:

Ok im going to do a simple tut on Java methods.

In order for a computer to do something you MUST tell it how, regretably its not as simple as

public class FixThisDamnCar {

public static void main(String args[])

{

FixTheDamnCar;

}

}

to be able to “fixthedamncar” you need to make a [glow=red,2,300]method[/glow] to tell it how.

A [glow=red,2,300]method[/glow] in Java is basicly a [glow=green,2,300]procedure[/glow] in Scar

a scar [glow=green,2,300]procedure[/glow] would look like this

procedure FixTheFuckingCarbonator;
begin
WriteLn('i need a wrench to do that dumbass');
end;

and the same in java

public static void FixTheFuckingCarbonator{

System.out.println("I need a wrench to do that dumbass");

}

so the full code may look like this

public class fixthisdamncar

{

public static void main(String args[]) 

{

FixTheFuckingCarbonator();

}

public static void FixTheFuckingCarbonator()
{

System.out.println("I need a wrench to do that dumbass");

}

}

Read full topic
